body:
That's not "defending" ideas, it's just an excuse for censorship. Theft would mean taking away someone's property, which doesn't happen in this case. What you've described is more like getting salty because someone saw something you had and decided to buy the same thing. By making that illegal, you are exerting control over what other people are allowed to do with their own property.

Also "ruining the legacy" is a moot point. It's very easy to see who produced something, so it's not like some random person can just change the canon if that's what you're thinking.

parent.body:
It's not the drawing of a picture that is the intellectual property. It's the trademark and uniqueness that the artist brought to the table.

A book with all the story and jibblets should be intellectual property, since it's a creation. A person has the right to defend such ideas and estate.

An inventor has the right to patent their invention. Same when someone discovers something like a cure for a disease.

Movies, comics, shows, they all need to have an owner or else anyone could barge in and ruin the legacy and it'll all be commie nonsense after that.

body:
The problem is if it's all on discord then people who aren't on discord can't really become part of ruqqus's community hardly at all. Since you have the vast majority of your discussions there, those of us who aren't in can give very little input and don't get to know the admins very well, nor the more prominent members of the community. I'd use it but unfortunately Discord thinks my IP is spam and forces me to enter a phone number unless I'm on mobile, on which it's too hard to use or type. It's resulted in a lot of miscommunications and confusion, and now some of the admins don't like me because I have to bother them with questions on Ruqqus threads instead of the discord. I'm definitely missing a lot by not being able to join, and I know I'm not alone.

Do you have any suggestions for me to improve communication for the time being?

parent.body:
I wouldn't say there's a real benefit to moving real time chat coms. on to ruqqus right now. We mostly use discord for quick communication and collaboration via voice/video conferences as well as added user feedback. I wouldn't say that we spend "most" of our time there as much as we use it as a tool to further our development goals. 

I do have some cool ideas on how we could integrate irc into ruqqus though. This would be really cool but is not currently a planned feature upgrade, just something we've discussed.

post.body:
This has been suggested many times. Currently ruqqus relies on Discord for pretty much all communication. That means for those of us who don't use Discord, or got banned from it for some reason, there is no way to contact or be contacted by other users, *including the admins*. Not being able to talk to other people is annoying, but having no method of communication with the *admins* outside of Discord is very concerning. Ruqqus needs to vastly improve its communication.

I think part of the problem is that it seems the admins right now spend more time on Discord than they do their own site. So they probably see this as a low priority since they don't really notice anyone who's not on the discord server, who are the ones having this problem. But as someone who doesn't use it, I can say this lack of communication and information is very frustrating, and based on my prior discussions I'm not alone. Ruqqus should not rely on discord for any of its functions, which it clearly does a lot currently. The real site should come way before the discord server, unfortunately right now the admins seem to be doing the opposite and engage with the discord server much more than they do the actual site, and that's causing a boatload of problems for non-discord users. The admins need to be aware that there are real users of this site who aren't on discord.

Update: They actually are planned! The admins have their hands full right now but it will come eventually. Thank you admins!

post.body:
(Obligatory I originally posted this on +CTH, but I figured it would reach a wider audience if I posted it here as well)

Lets be real, as much as the end to the war on drugs is being painfully slow, its coming eventually. I frankly think the war on drugs has been the single most harmful American policy since segregation too, but thats besides the point.

Anyhow, lets start with marijuana, since that is the only drug we have made any federal progress on really (hemp legalization and banking only), and the only drug states have legalized.

Anyhow, I suspect what is going to happen with this on a federal level is some time in the next four years we will see the feds stop dealing with it at least. I am not hopeful the feds will mandate legalization in all states under a biden administration, but at this point the amount of states with marijuana programs that do not align with federal law vastly outnumber the States in compliance, so we may see something like the STATES act pass soon (probably not for the next two years though tbh) which exempts marijuana from the CSA either federally or from a federal standpoint in legal states. For the average user, all this would mean is you can now order it in the mail perhaps if you are in a legal state, you can legally bring it across legal states lines, and you would not technically lose your firearms rights the second you buy a joint unless your state says otherwise. From a distribution standpoint, this would probably mean big interstate cannabis conglomerates may be able to form, which while shitty, means that it will be able to lobby states into legalizing much quicker, although expect some big tobacco level control of weed as a result of this in the coming decades.

overall though, much like the end of prohibition, I do not see the feds mandating states legalize it for decades to come if at all. So if you are in Alabama, you may be out of luck for a few decades still until big marijuana gets big enough to lobby otherwise, but I think most States will be legalized in 10 years, and the illegal states will be the exception not the norm.

Now, other drugs is where I think we face a larger uphill battle. Currently, the only progress we have really made so far is Denver decriminalizing mushrooms, a town or two in California deceiminalizing psychedelics, and a police department in Pennsylvania refusing to enforce any drug laws (the cop behind this very well may be my only exception to ACAB). We have nothing on a statewide level, let alone national level, for any other drugs.

However, I think this year may mark the first year we make some serious progress at least towards general decriminalization, as Oregon is slated to have a ballot initiative in the 2020 election, which if passed, will decriminalize possession of all drugs within the state, and Washington DC also has a ballot proposal to decriminalize some psychedelics (The Oregon proposal is much more important and is a much wider scope than the DC proposal, which can be overruled by Congress, and only makes it a "low police priority" and asks the DA nicely to not prosecute).

Sadly though, I think we are going to basically be starting back at square one with all other drugs just like we had to with marijuana. It will likely be many decades before we see anything federal, and even then it would likely just be a STATES act for all drugs on the CSA or something, not federally mandated legalization.

in the meantime though, what I suspect we will see with the legalization of other drugs is some states decriminalizing slowly one by one, with medical programs slowly being introduced for things like mushrooms, mdma, and LSD, which eventually morph into recreational legality in certain states like we have seen with marijuana, which, after decades, will probably create a states act situation like we are on the verge of with marijuana. Psychedelics will eventually be legal in all 50 states probably, but expect it to take a similar amount of time it takes for weed to be legal in all 50, so it may sadly not be in your lifetime.

What about genuinely harmful drugs like Meth though you may ask?

Eh, hate to break it to you, but I doubt you will be able to buy that stuff legally in your lifetime, dont get me wrong, it is unlikely to remain a criminal offence to possess in every state or even federally depending on how the psychedelic states act is written, but at the same time I don't see a path beyond decriminalization for these types of things right now. They have next to no medical value given we already use legal version of this stuff for prescription drugs, and recreationally these types of drugs have clearly been shown to cause more harm than good. I don't think we will be locking up meth dealers for decades like we always have forever though, because I do expect we will have some more general criminal justice reform as well, but overall I don't really see a path forward to "meth dispensaries" whatsoever right now.

For the legalization of all drugs, period, Maybe society will be ready for that in like 70-100+ years, im not sure, but I don't expect to see that any time in my lifetime in a broad manor in the United States, and I can not even attempt to predict what the path forward for that would look like given the current information and situation.

That being said, I care far more about psychedelics than legalizing meth.

DMss are one of the next things on the list.

They are. We're juggling a lot of different projects, ranging from performance improvements (which outrank everything else if there's a problem), efficiency improvements, and all manner of new features.

We implemented user blocking a little bit ago, which was a prerequisite feature to DMs.

My current project is API work, which will allow people to make third party clients and apps.

DMss are one of the next things on the list.

post.body:
This has been suggested many times. Currently ruqqus relies on Discord for pretty much all communication. That means for those of us who don't use Discord, or got banned from it for some reason, there is no way to contact or be contacted by other users, *including the admins*. Not being able to talk to other people is annoying, but having no method of communication with the *admins* outside of Discord is very concerning. Ruqqus needs to vastly improve its communication.

I think part of the problem is that it seems the admins right now spend more time on Discord than they do their own site. So they probably see this as a low priority since they don't really notice anyone who's not on the discord server, who are the ones having this problem. But as someone who doesn't use it, I can say this lack of communication and information is very frustrating, and based on my prior discussions I'm not alone. Ruqqus should not rely on discord for any of its functions, which it clearly does a lot currently. The real site should come way before the discord server, unfortunately right now the admins seem to be doing the opposite and engage with the discord server much more than they do the actual site, and that's causing a boatload of problems for non-discord users. The admins need to be aware that there are real users of this site who aren't on discord.

Update: They actually are planned! The admins have their hands full right now but it will come eventually. Thank you admins!

body:
I tend to look at objectivism as a similar conclusion but for the opposite reason. Objectivism actually advocates for being an asshole who only cares about yourself. Libertarians typically want the selfish government assholes to stop bothering everyone. This would include the *right* to act like a selfish jerk, but definitely doesn't *promote* being like that.

Interestingly, selfish people typically have no moral deterrence from trying to control and rule as many things as they can, and as a result they make up almost all of government. So Ayn Rand is just odd to me.

post.body:
This has been suggested many times. Currently ruqqus relies on Discord for pretty much all communication. That means for those of us who don't use Discord, or got banned from it for some reason, there is no way to contact or be contacted by other users, *including the admins*. Not being able to talk to other people is annoying, but having no method of communication with the *admins* outside of Discord is very concerning. Ruqqus needs to vastly improve its communication.

I think part of the problem is that it seems the admins right now spend more time on Discord than they do their own site. So they probably see this as a low priority since they don't really notice anyone who's not on the discord server, who are the ones having this problem. But as someone who doesn't use it, I can say this lack of communication and information is very frustrating, and based on my prior discussions I'm not alone. Ruqqus should not rely on discord for any of its functions, which it clearly does a lot currently. The real site should come way before the discord server, unfortunately right now the admins seem to be doing the opposite and engage with the discord server much more than they do the actual site, and that's causing a boatload of problems for non-discord users. The admins need to be aware that there are real users of this site who aren't on discord.

Update: They actually are planned! The admins have their hands full right now but it will come eventually. Thank you admins!

parent.body:
I don't support open borders. In my opinion enforcing borders and immigration law is one of the few legitimate functions of the state. Without a border and without an official legal process to become a citizen, then how do you even have a country?

Maybe the immigration process in the US needs to be overhauled, but I don't think that we should just open up the border and invite everyone across freely.
parent.body_html:
I don't support open borders. In my opinion enforcing borders and immigration law is one of the few legitimate functions of the state. Without a border and without an official legal process to become a citizen, then how do you even have a country?

Maybe the immigration process in the US needs to be overhauled, but I don't think that we should just open up the border and invite everyone across freely.
